question: Question_10_(a)
statement:
Let $A \subset \mathbb R$ be a bounded set of real numbers and let
$B \subseteq A$ be a nonempty subset of \emph{A}. Prove that \emph{B} is
also bounded and that

\begin{align*}\inf(A) \leq \sup(B) \leq \sup(A).\end{align*}
sols:
By definition of the supremum of a set, sup(\emph{B}) is the smallest
real number that is larger or equal to all the numbers in the set
\emph{B}. Since all the numbers of the set \emph{B} are also numbers of
the set \emph{A}, we can conclude that sup(\emph{A}) is also larger or
equal to all the numbers of the set \emph{B} (since it is larger or
equal to all numbers in the set \emph{A}) but since sup(\emph{B}) is the
smallest real number with that property we can conclude that

\begin{align*}\sup(B) \leq \sup(A)\end{align*}

Now inf(\emph{A}) is a number that is less or equal than any number in
the set \emph{A} and so since \emph{B} is a subset, it is in particular
less or equal to any number in the set \emph{B}. Since sup(\emph{B}) is
larger than any number in the set \emph{B} we can conclude that

\begin{align*}\inf(A) \leq \sup(B)\end{align*}

\textbf{\emph{Note:}} \emph{we could actually prove the more interesting
and stronger statement:}

\begin{align*}\inf(A) \leq \inf(B) \leq \sup(B) \leq \sup(A).\end{align*}
hints:
Recall the definition of
\href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supremum}{supremum} and
\href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infimum}{infimum} of sets of real
numbers.
